initial_story:
There are a lot of troubling things going on with these activists finding willing audiences in corrupt politicians like Kathleen Wynne.  Just as they are trying to censor this brilliant and refreshing documentary on Dr. Zucker, (I'd encourage you to look into this heroic professional who was black listed by these career, taxpayer bleeding, social justice warriors and militant activists), they did the same thing with the Ontario Sex Ed curriculum.  They banned any parental feedback and deferred to the activist themselves to review it and approve it, despite the fact that it heavily promotes gender diasphora, and the fantasies of Ben Levin.

These totalitarians operate under the guise of gaining equality for a supposed marginalized group, but are willing to go scorched earth with your children to get what they want.  If you don't go along you're branded a homophobe or ignorant, but ask them for any scientific evidence and they'll trot out some junk science and personally attack you.

It's the 21st century and the world is a different place. Technology has advanced in leaps and bounds, and with it, society has changed too. One of the most significant changes has been in the way we view gender and sexuality. No longer are we confined to the traditional binary of male and female; instead, we are free to explore and express our own unique identities.

But as our understanding of gender and sexuality has evolved, so too has the way we teach our children about these important topics. In the past, sex education was often limited to a discussion of the biological differences between men and women and the mechanics of reproduction. But today, many schools and parents are taking a more holistic approach, recognizing that sex education is about more than just the physical act of sex; it's also about understanding and respecting our own bodies and those of others.

Unfortunately, not everyone is on board with this new approach. Some people still cling to outdated beliefs about gender and sexuality, and they are using their influence to try to censor and control what our children learn in school. They argue that these new curricula are too "radical" or "controversial," and that they are promoting a dangerous agenda.

But the truth is, these new curricula are not radical or dangerous. They are simply reflecting the reality of the world we live in today, where gender and sexuality are more fluid and diverse than ever before. They are giving our children the tools they need to navigate this complex and ever-changing world, and to make informed and responsible decisions about their own lives.

So let's not be swayed by the fear-mongering and misinformation of those who would censor and control our children's education. Instead, let's embrace the future and give our children the knowledge and understanding they need to thrive in the world we've created for them.
